abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Municipal Development
            Project in Guatemala are as follows: overall outcome of the
            project is rated as satisfactory, and the performance of the
            Bank and the Borrower were also rated as satisfactory. Some
            of the lessons learned from the project are: 1)
            participatory development should be given a chance,
            especially where governance is weak at the local level
            Guatemala's experience in participatory development has
            proved successful and might be applicable to one of more of
            the following conditions in other countries too: (i) post
            conflict situations; (ii) volatile political and
            institutional environment; and (iii) local-level government
            undermined or even non-existent because of excessive
            centralism; 2) participatory development requires intensive
            supervision on the ground of the kind that United Nations
            Children's Fund (UNICEF) provided efficiently. In
            addition to the Bank's own regular supervision,
            participatory development operations require intensive
            day-to-day management of the kind that UNICEF provided so
            effectively under this project; and 3) participatory
            development is not necessarily a final solution, but is an
            important way station on the route to more solid local
            institutional development. Participatory development should
            not allow local government to relinquish responsibilities
            toward its poorer constituents. Thus, participatory
            development should be complementary to the long-term pursuit
            of municipal l reform of the kind originally envisioned by
            this project.
